National Frontiers Science Center for Industrial Intelligence and Systems Optimization, Northeastern University Shenyang 110819 China To reduce the carbon monoxide (CO) emissions in sintering flue gas, this study employed a catalytic oxidation approach to convert CO into carbon dioxide (CO2) at low temperatures. The Cu-Mn catalysts were synthesized using co-precipitation methods. The effects of various reaction conditions, such as the Cu/Mn ratio and reaction temperatures, on CO catalytic efficiency was investigated. The results indicated that when the Cu/Mn ratio was 1:2, the catalytic efficiency was 98.34 % at approximately 105 °C. Furthermore, the catalysts remained stable after continuous testing. Based on density functional theory (DFT), a model for the adsorption of CO molecules was established. The adsorption characteristics between CuMn2O4 and CO, as well as the changes in surface charge distribution before and after adsorption, were systematically investigated. The research results indicated that the adsorption of CO on the surface of CuMn2O4 is a chemical adsorption process. Among the various adsorption sites, CO exhibits a greater affinity for the Mn-top site, with an adsorption energy of − 1.18 eV. During the adsorption process, some electrons from CO are transferred to the surface of the catalyst, resulting in orbital hybridization. Additionally, this paper investigated the reaction pathways involved in the CO oxidation process. These findings provide new insights for the optimization and screening of catalysts, which are significant for the fields of industrial flue gas purification and catalytic science. Graphical Abstract Keywords Low temperature catalysis Catalytic activity Density functional theory Surface adsorption Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Industrial waste gases have become the primary source of air pollution [1,2]. In iron and steel industry, ultra-low emission initiatives have effectively reduced pollutions such as PM10/2.5, SO2, and NO x [3]. However, CO remains one of the relatively high components in the waste gases. During the sintering process, the CO concentration ranges from 8000 to 10,000 mg/Nm3, which is approximately 800 times, 228 times, and 160 times higher than the concentrations of PM10/2.5, SO2, and NO x , respectively. CO is produced by the incomplete combustion of fuel, contributing to a sintering heat loss ranging from 1.19 to 1.42 × 10⁹ GJ per year [4]. As a pollutant, CO participates in redox reaction with ozone, reducing atmospheric ozone levels. Additionally, it also reacts photochemically with non-methane total hydrocarbons (NMHC) in the air, resulting in the formation of photochemical smog. Consequently, the management of CO emissions has gradually become a critical issue of concern in the iron and steel industry [5–7]. The challenge of reducing CO emissions has received significant attention. Catalytic oxidation technology provides an efficient solution for CO removal while also reducing operational costs for enterprises. This approach is widely regarded as one of the safest and most economical methods for purification. Additionally, the CO catalytic oxidation reaction is exothermic, with the specific heat of flue gas measured at 1.36 kJ/m3. When the concentration of CO decreases from 10,000 ppm to 2000 ppm, the reaction releases 283 kJ/mol, elevating the theoretical flue gas temperature by 74.3 °C. By leveraging this characteristic, an optimal reaction temperature can be established for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) processes [8], effectively removing NO x from sintering flue gas [9–12]. In summary, employing catalytic oxidation methods is crucial for addressing CO emissions. Fig. 1 illustrates the process of CO catalytic oxidation and the associated increase in flue gas temperature. Currently, researchers have been committed to explore the efficiency of CO catalytic oxidation and developing more efficient and cost-effective catalysts [13–17]. At present, the catalysts are divided into two categories: precious metal catalysts and non-precious metal catalysts [18]. The commonly used precious metal catalysts include Pt, Pd, Rh, Au, which offer high catalytic efficiency, excellent resistance to poisoning, and strong stability [19–23]. However, it is difficult to be widely applied in industry due to the high cost. The active components of non-precious metal catalysts suitable for CO catalytic oxidation mainly include transition metal such as Cu, Mn, Ni, Co, Ce, Fe and their oxides [24–29]. These catalysts can effectively serve as substitutes for precious metal catalysts to some extent, through appropriate preparation methods and synergistic composition of components. Xie et al. [30] successfully synthesized the rod-like structure of nanometer Co3O4 and studied its catalytic performance. The results showed that the catalyst can achieve complete oxidation of CO at a low temperature of − 77 °C, and the catalyst continued to exhibit excellent catalytic activity under 3–10 ppm water vapor conditions. Feng et al. [31] pointed out that TiO2 also showed high catalytic performance for CO. Luo et al. [32] prepared a CuO-CeO2 catalyst with high specific surface area by surfactant template method. When the Cu content exceeded 12 %, the catalytic activity of the catalyst reached 90 % and at a temperature of 80 °C. Jung et al. [33] prepared a series of Cu-Ce catalysts by the co-precipitation method and trialed the catalytic activity for CO in the presence of excess H2 and CO2. The results showed that when the roasting temperature is 700 °C, the temperature of CO transformation is 160 °C. Behar et al. [34] found that the catalytic activity of copper oxide was lower than that of Mn3O4 under the condition of pure oxide. Among these materials, Mn-based catalysts are cost-effective, less toxic, and exhibit excellent catalytic performance [35,36]. However, their oxygen load is low, and Mn2O3 can only be reduced to Mn3O4 or MnO. The Cu-based catalysts with high CuO content will encounter agglomeration problems during experiments [37]. Single component Mn or Cu oxides have limitations in catalytic efficiency. Xu et al. [38] found that adding copper can effectively improve the reactivity of manganese ore. In addition, Wang et al. [39] pointed out that CuMn2O4 showed excellent reaction performance compared with the single metal oxide of Mn. The Cu-Mn catalysts make use of their respective characteristics to produce a synergistic effect, which makes them have better performance. Besides, the low-temperature characteristics of sintering flue gas usually reduce the catalytic activity of some catalytic materials. CuMn2O4 catalysts are not only cost-effective but also capable of maintaining high catalytic efficiency at low temperatures, making them highly suitable for various applications. However, few have attempted to explore how the copper and manganese elements exhibit synergistic effects in catalyzing CO, and the influence of the copper to manganese element ratio and different synthesis methods on the structure and performance of catalyst have not been clearly indicated. In addition, the reaction mechanism of CO on the surface of the catalyst is not yet clear. Confront with the current situation of insufficient research, it is necessary to conduct systematic experimental and theoretical studies on this catalytic process. In this paper, the catalytic efficiency of the CuMn2O4 catalyst for CO oxidation and the reaction mechanism of the catalytic process were systematically studied through experiments and theoretical calculations. The element distribution and surface morphology of the catalyst were characterized, and the effects of element ratios, reaction temperature, and other conditions on the catalyst's activity were evaluated. Furthermore, the stability of the catalytic reaction process was verified by 53 h continuous test. Finally, the potential reaction pathway of CO oxidation on CuMn2O4 surface was determined by density functional theory (DFT) calculation. The results of this study contribute to a comprehensive understanding of the reaction mechanism between CuMn2O4 and CO and provide a theoretical basis for the improvement of catalysts. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation Cu-Mn catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation (C-P) methods. The raw materials required for the C-P method were copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O), manganese nitrate (50 wt% Mn(NO3)2), sodium carbonate (Na2CO3) and deionized water (H2O). All chemical reagents utilized in this experiment were sourced from commercial suppliers and can be used without any additional processing. The preparation steps of the catalyst were as follows. Mixed solutions of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 50 wt% Mn(NO3)2 were prepared in molar ratios (Cu/Mn) of 1:3, 1:2, 1:1, and 2:1, respectively. Meanwhile, continuously stir the solution with a magnetic stirrer for two hours. Then, the mixed solution was slowly added to the Na2CO3 solution while stirring vigorously to create an alkaline environment (PH = 9–10) and form a preliminary precipitate. Furthermore, the precipitate is vacuum filtered and washed 5 times with deionized water or ethanol to remove impurity ions. Next, transfer the samples to a blast drying oven and dry them at 110 °C for 12 h. Finally, the samples are calcined at 700 °C for 4 h, then cooled to room temperature, crushed, and prepared for use (150–200 mesh). 2.2 Catalytic characterization XRD (SmartLab SE) was used to test the crystalline phase composition of the catalyst [40–43]. The XRD graphics were obtained from 10° to 90° under operating of 40 kV and 30 mA. The XRD results can show the crystallographic phases and crystal planes of materials. The element distribution on the surface of the catalyst was tested by XPS (Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi), which was operated at 15 kV. The binding energy was adjusted using the C1s peak at 284.8 eV. The surface structure of CuMn2O4 before and after the reaction was explored using SEM (Zeiss Sigma 300). A high-resolution transmission electron microscope (TEM, F200X G2) was employed to analyze the lattice structure of the catalyst. The elemental distribution was showed by EDS detector at 20 kV. The NOVA 4200e (Quantachrome, USA) was used to gain N2 absorption-desorption curves, testing the physical parameters of the catalyst. All catalytic materials were pretreated at 150 °C to remove water, thus ensuring the accuracy of the test results. 2.3 Catalytic performance test The evaluation setup for CO catalytic oxidation performance is illustrated in Fig. 2. The experimental apparatus primarily comprises a gas distribution system, a reaction system, and a flue gas analysis system. The catalytic activity of the copper-manganese catalyst for CO oxidation was tested in a fixed-bed reactor constructed from glass tubes, measuring 650 mm in length and 9 mm in inner diameter. Prior to the experiment, quartz cotton was used to support the catalyst (0.75 g), which was positioned at the center of the constant temperature zone. In this study, the catalytic oxidation activity and stability of the catalyst were thoroughly investigated. The inlet gases, with varying CO and O2 concentrations, were regulated using mass flow controllers. In this process, program parameters were set to explore the catalytic efficiency of the catalyst under different working conditions (temperature, CO, O2 concentration, etc.). This process mainly involves the following reactions, as shown in Eq. (1). (1) CO + 1 2 O 2 = CO 2 The conversion efficiency of CO in the experiment was calculated according to the reduction of CO, as shown in Eq. (2). (2) x CO ( % ) = ( [ CO ] in − [ CO ] out ) / [ CO ] in × 100 % Where, [CO]in and [CO]out represented the total amount of CO before the reaction and the output of CO after the reaction, respectively. 2.4 Computational details All calculations were based on density functional theory [44–47]. During the structural optimization process, the convergence criteria of self-consistent iterative cycles in the electronic step, ionic step relaxation, and cut-off energy were 10−6 eV/Å, 0.01 eV/Å and 500 eV, respectively. The conjugate gradient method was used in the ionic step relaxation algorithm. Since both Cu and Mn elements contain d orbitals, the U values of 6 eV and 2.5 eV were introduced for correction [48]. The Brillouin region division was performed by the Gamma method and 4 × 2 × 1 was used as the k point for subsequent calculations. In addition, a vacuum layer with a thickness of 15 Å was constructed in the surface model. The larger the adsorption energy, the more stable the adsorption structure, and the definition of adsorption energy (E ads) was expressed by the Eq. (3). (3) E ads = E total − E CO ( E O 2 ) − E sur Where, E total, E sur, E CO and E O2 represent the energies of the entire adsorption system, CuMn2O4(100) surface, and the isolated CO or O2 molecule, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance analysis 3.1.1 Influence of Cu/Mn ratio on catalytic efficiency Fig. 3(a, b) depicted the evaluation effect of the CO catalytic reaction of catalysts synthesized with different Cu-Mn ratios. The composition of catalysts prepared with different Cu/Mn ratios varies, as shown in Fig. 7. When the Cu/Mn ratio is 1:2, relatively pure CuMn2O4 can be formed. The catalyst components prepared in other proportions are mainly CuMn2O4 and CuO. In addition, with the increase of copper content, the content of CuO in the components will continue to increase. Fig. 3(a) shows the variation in CO concentration as a function of temperature throughout the experimental process. Fig. 3(b) illustrates the catalytic oxidation activity of CO for catalysts prepared with varying ratios of Cu to Mn. The catalytic efficiency of Cu1Mn3 for CO at 30 °C was about 6 %, and the stable conversion temperature of CO was about 108 °C, with a conversion efficiency of 98.31 %. With the increase of Cu content to 1:2 and 1:1, the activity of catalyst increased slightly, and the conversion rate was 98.34 % at approximately 105 °C. However, when the CuO content in the catalyst component is high, it will reduce the CO catalytic effect. The Cu2Mn1 catalyst had almost no catalytic effect at 30 °C, and the CO conversion temperature was about 125 °C, with a conversion efficiency of 95.59 %. The results indicated that Cu1Mn2 and Cu1Mn1 catalysts have an excellent catalytic effect on CO. 3.1.2 Concentration analysis of CO and O2 In industrial production, the proportions of different gases change dynamically. Consequently, the influence of CO and O2 concentrations on the catalytic efficiency of the CuMn2O4 was investigated. The concentrations of CO and O2 were adjusted independently by setting the parameters of the flow meters. The reaction activity tests were conducted, as shown in Fig. 4. The results showed that the catalyst has shown preliminary catalytic efficiency at 30 °C, with efficiencies of 11.91 %, 6.67 %, and 2.74 %, respectively (see Fig. 4(a)). The CO conversion gradually increases with rising temperature, with the fastest growth observed in the range of 70–80 °C. When the reaction temperature exceeded 100 °C, the conversion rates of the three concentrations became nearly identical. At the same temperature, the conversion efficiency of low-concentration CO was higher than that of high-concentration CO. This phenomenon is hypothesized to result from a competitive relationship between CO and O2, which reduces the catalytic efficiency. Subsequently, this section will be further analyzed through theoretical calculations. Fig. 4(b) illustrates the effect of oxygen concentration on catalytic efficiency. In the experiment, the oxygen concentration was maintained within a range of 9–15 %. The image illustrates that under low-temperature conditions, the effect of oxygen concentration on catalytic activity is relatively minimal. However, when the experimental temperature exceeds 70 °C, a positive correlation is observed between oxygen concentration and catalytic efficiency. 3.1.3 Continuity testing Continuity testing evaluates the long-term stability of the catalyst, a critical factor in determining its viability for practical industrial applications. The terminal temperature range of industrial flue gas is typically between 120 °C and 180 °C. Therefore, 120 °C was selected as the test temperature. Fig. 5 showed that under the condition of 120 °C, there were some slight fluctuations in the CO conversion rate during the test. However, from the perspective of the entire reaction process, the catalyst consistently maintained an excellent catalytic conversion effect on CO. The result showed that the catalyst has strong stability. 3.2 Catalyst characterization analysis N₂ adsorption-desorption tests were performed on the prepared catalysts. Fig. 6 shows the isothermal curves and pore size distributions of nitrogen adsorption and desorption for various catalyst types. As shown in Fig. 6(a), the nitrogen adsorption isotherms closely resemble Type III isotherms. Additionally, Fig. 6(b) indicates that the pore sizes range from 2 to 30 nm, confirming that all materials are mesoporous. The specific surface area and total pore volume were listed in Table 1, showing relatively small values, which were attributed to the calcination temperature [49,50]. Samples with Cu/Mn ratios of 1:3, 1:2, 1:1, and 2:1 were prepared by the C-P method, and their XRD patterns were shown in Fig. 7(a). When the Cu/Mn ratio was 1:2, the diffraction peak positions of the catalyst matched the CuMn2O4 phase (JCPDS 84-0543). The prepared catalyst exhibited numerous sharp peaks with minimal impurity peaks, indicating a high degree of purity. When the Cu/Mn ratio was 2:1, the excess Cu led to the presence of significant amounts of copper oxide in the prepared samples, resulting in decreased catalyst activity, which was consistent with the experimental results mentioned above. In addition, the XRD patterns of CuMn2O4 before and after the experiment were shown in Fig. 7(b). The images showed that the composition of CuMn2O4 before and after the reaction was almost unchanged, indicating that the catalyst had strong stability. Therefore, CuMn2O4 will be chosen as the main research object in the future. Furthermore, SEM characterization was performed on CuMn2O4 before and after the reaction to observe the changes in catalyst surface, as shown in Fig. 8. Fig. 8(a, c) and Fig. 8(b, d) show the morphology of the catalyst before and after the reaction, respectively. The images reveal that the CuMn2O4 catalyst possesses a homogeneous particle structure as well as a loose and porous surface morphology, which facilitates CO adsorption on the catalyst surface. Compared with the catalyst before the reaction, the particle size of the catalyst after the reaction did not change significantly, and the pore structure increased to a certain extent, making the surface of the catalyst looser than that before the reaction. The typical octahedral spinel structure of the catalyst can be clearly observed from Fig. 8(c, d), which was consistent with the XRD analysis results. Furthermore, Fig. 8(e, f) present the TEM images obtained during the tests. The images show different crystal surfaces of the catalyst, including the (220) and (400) planes, which correspond to lattice spacings of 0.18 nm and 0.25 nm, respectively. The TEM test results were consistent with the XRD analysis results. In addition, EDS analysis of the catalyst was performed. As shown in Fig. 8(g), the sample contained Cu, Mn, and O, which were evenly distributed throughout. It indicated that the synthesis method of the catalyst was advantageous for elemental dispersion, further confirming its stability and activity in the catalytic reaction. Furthermore, the surface composition and chemical environment of the catalytic materials were characterized by XPS. The valence states and relative contents of elements (Cu, Mn, and O) on the surface of the sample were determined by XPS analysis, and the results were shown in Fig. 9. Fig. 9(a, c, and e) were the XPS spectra of elements O, Mn, and Cu before the catalyst reaction, while Fig. 9(b, d, and f) were the XPS spectra of elements O, Mn, and Cu after the catalyst reaction, respectively. Fig. 9(a) showed that the XPS spectrum of O1s mainly consisted of three peaks, Oα, Oβ, and Oγ [51,52]. The peaks at 529.66 eV, 531.04 eV and 534.11 eV were attributed to lattice oxygen (Oα), low-coordinated oxygen species (Oβ) adsorbed in oxygen vacancies, and oxygen (Oγ) from water molecules attached to the catalyst surface, respectively [53]. The data showed that the area ratio of the three characteristic peaks was 57.12 %, 41.89 % and 0.99 %, respectively. Fig. 9(b) showed the XPS spectral image of the catalytic material after the reaction, in which the area of the Oα peak decreased, while the area of the Oβ increased to a certain extent, and the peak area of these three oxygens was 53.15 %, 45.90 % and 0.95 %, respectively. By comparing of the above data, it was found that the proportion of lattice oxygen and oxygen vacancies changed before and after the reaction. The lattice oxygen content decreased, while the oxygen vacancy content increased, indicating that the catalytic oxidation of CO on the CuMn2O4 surface followed the MvK mechanism. Fig. 9(c, d) showed the Mn2p orbit, the characteristic peak at 641.2 eV, 653.3 eV and 642.8 eV corresponded to Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+, respectively. Fig. 9(d, e) showed that the peak located at the binding energy of 930.92 eV represents Cu2p3/2, corresponding to Cu+ in the catalytic material, and the peaks of 933.79 eV and 961.85 eV can be attributed to Cu2+. However, Cu+ phase was not observed in their XRD patterns, suggesting that Cu+ species were formed on the surface of the material rather than in the body phase of the crystal. The images revealed that the valence state of Cu remained largely unchanged, while the proportions of Mn2+ and Mn4+ exhibited slight variations before and after the reaction. However, the overall changes were minimal, suggesting that the CuMn2O4 catalyst demonstrated robust stability throughout the process. 3.3 Model construction and optimization The structure of CuMn2O4 was optimized (see Fig. 10(b)), with the k-point set to 4 × 4 × 4. After optimization, the lattice parameter of CuMn2O4 was determined to be a = b = c = 8.518 Å, which is consistent with the experimental data (8.327 Å) [54]. The CO model is shown in Fig. 10(d). The experimental results showed that the bond length of CO was 1.128 Å, while the calculation result showed that it was 1.144 Å. The two values were similar, indicating that the chosen method and parameter settings were reasonable. The choice of surface adsorption model was crucial for subsequent studies on the mechanism of CO adsorption and oxidation. The CuMn2O4 (100) surface exhibits catalytic activity and represents the most thermodynamically stable low-index surface, which is readily exposed to air [53,54]. Therefore, it was selected to study the mechanism of CO molecule adsorption and oxidation. The front and top views are shown in Fig. 10(a, c), respectively. In Fig. 10(a), the potential active sites were marked. The entire surface model included five-coordinated Mn sites, four-coordinated Cu sites, and three-coordinated O sites, where O1 was connected to three Mn atoms and O2 was connected to two Mn atoms and one Cu atom. To investigate the possible adsorption models of CO on the CuMn2O4(100) surface, the adsorption energies of CO on different metal top sites (Mn, Cu) and bridge sites between metal and oxygen atoms were calculated. By comparing the adsorption energies and bond length changes, the preferred adsorption sites were selected. Fig. 11 showed the stable adsorption model of CO at different adsorption sites. CO can be stably adsorbed on Mn and Cu top sites, as well as Mn-O1 and Mn-O2 bridge sites, with specific parameters listed in Table 2. In the adsorption model Mn-top, CO was vertically adsorbed at the Mn atom, and the adsorption energy was 1.183 eV, which belonged to stable chemisorption. In this model, the C-O bond of CO changed from the initial 1.144 Å to 1.161 Å, indicating that CO was activated. At the same time, C and Mn atoms combined to form a C-Mn bond with a length of 1.952 Å. For the bridge site adsorption model, the CO can also be stably adsorbed on the Mn-O1 bridge site, forming new CO1 and CMn bonds with lengths of 1.331 Å and 2.042 Å, respectively. When CO was adsorbed on the Mn-O2 bridge site, the newly formed CO and MnO bond lengths were 1.315 Å and 2.012 Å, respectively, with an adsorption energy of 0.78 eV. The results showed that the bridge-2 model has a higher adsorption energy than the bridge-1 model, indicating that the addition of Cu can enhance the activity of the O element, forming a more stable adsorption model with CO. It corresponds to the experimental results. 3.4 Analysis of adsorption mechanism 3.4.1 Charge analysis Fig. 12 showed the differential charge density diagram of CO adsorption at adjacent Mn-top position. The yellow and blue regions represented the increase and decrease of charges, respectively. The image showed that the charge density of CO molecules and adjacent Mn atoms decreased, and the charge was transferred towards their middle area. The transfer of charge promoted the adsorption of C atom on the CuMn2O4 surface, forming C-Mn chemical bonds, which further explained that this adsorption belonged to chemical adsorption. To understand the charge transfer situation in the system, the charge change of the whole system was calculated and analyzed quantitatively. The charge transfer and bond length changes of CO before and after adsorption on CuMn2O4(100) surface were analyzed, and the results were shown in Table 3. The CO bond length of CO changed from 1.144 Å to 1.152 Å, indicating that CO had been activated. In a free state, the charges on the C and O atoms were − 1.08 and 1.08, respectively. After adsorption, these charges became − 0.93 and 1.05, respectively, and the total charge of CO became 0.12. This indicated that charge transfer occurred during the process, with some charges transferred to the surface of CuMn2O4, resulting in electron redistribution and promoting the formation of chemical bonds, which was consistent with the results of differential charge density. 3.4.2 Density of state analysis The density of states of Mn atom and CO molecule, both before and after adsorption, were calculated. As shown in Fig. 13, compared to the state before adsorption, the adsorption process appeared surface electronic states of Mn atoms in the energy ranges of − 7.5 eV to − 6 eV and 0 eV to − 2.5 eV. Similarly, CO also exhibited surface electronic states in the energy ranges of − 7.5 eV to − 6 eV, − 6 eV to − 5 eV, and 0 eV to − 2.5 eV. Changes in the ranges of − 7.5 eV to − 6 eV and − 6 eV to − 5 eV were minimal, while more significant peak shifts occurred in the range of 0 eV to − 2.5 eV. In addition, the maximum peak values on the two surfaces before and after adsorption were 2.46 and 2.31, respectively. This indicates that charge transfer occurs during CO adsorption, which is the main reason for chemisorption of Mn sites with CO molecules. To investigate the orbital components of the surface, atomic orbital density images were obtained. Fig. 14(a, c) illustrate the orbital state density images of the three elements, C, O, and Mn, respectively. The results reveal that the hybridization between the molecular orbitals of CO and the atomic orbitals of Mn within the energy range of − 7.5 eV to − 6 eV predominantly arises from the interaction of the p orbitals of the C atom, the py and pz orbitals of the O atom, and the s, p, and d orbitals of the Mn atom. Within the energy range of − 6 eV to − 5 eV, the hybridization was primarily attributed to the interaction between the s orbitals of the C atom, the pz orbitals of the C and O atoms, and the d and s orbitals of the Mn atom. Similarly, in the energy range of 0 eV to 2.5 eV, the hybridization predominantly originated from the interaction between the p orbitals of the C and O atoms and the d orbitals of the Mn atom. 3.5 CO catalytic oxidation reaction pathway Based on the analysis of the XPS data, it was observed that the content of lattice oxygen changed, indicating the involvement of lattice oxygen in the catalytic oxidation of CO, following the MvK mechanism. Due to the presence of different active oxygen species on the catalyst surface, the CO oxidation process to CO2 was divided into two distinct reaction pathways. And the process can be divided into three stages, CO adsorption, CO2 formation, and CO2 desorption. The free CO and CuMn2O4 surfaces were defined as the initial structure (IS), the free CO2 and CuMn2O4 surfaces with oxygen vacancies were defined as the final structure (FS). According to the previous analysis, the adsorption energy of CO adsorbed at the Mn-top position was greater than the adsorption energy at the bridge position, which indicated that CO was preferentially adsorbed at the Mn-top position. Therefore, the oxidation mechanism and reaction pathway of the process were as follows: free CO was gradually adsorbed at the Mn-top positions, then overcame the reaction energy barrier to migrate to the Mn-O bridge sites, and then combined with the lattice oxygen on the surface of CuMn2O4 to form CO2, and finally CO2 detached from the surface. Fig. 15(a) illustrated the path change process of CO adsorption at the Mn-top position. In the first stage, CO was adsorbed on the Mn-top site, migrating to the Mn-O1 bridge site through the transition state, and forming a new Mn-O bond. In the TS1 configuration, the C-Mn bond length changed from 1.952 Å to 1.964 Å, while the CO molecule was tilted toward O1, with a spacing of 1.840 Å between them. This process overcomes a reaction energy barrier of 0.95 eV. Subsequently, CO combined with lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface to transform into CO2 and underwent the transition state TS2 to complete CO2 detachment, a process that requires overcoming an energy of 0.381 eV, resulting in CO2 bond lengths of 1.172 Å and 1.181 Å, respectively. In path 1, the rate-limiting step is the combination of CO and lattice oxygen at the surface, whereas in path 2, the rate-limiting step is CO2 desorption. The catalyst, which contains oxygen vacancies, adsorbs O2 from the air and gradually returns to its initial state. The process can also be divided into three stages, O2 adsorption, CO adsorption, and CO2 desorption. The model consisting of free O2 and CuMn2O4 surfaces with oxygen vacancies, as well as the model of free CO and CuMn2O4 surfaces, were defined as the initial structures (IS). The model consisting of free CO2 and CuMn2O4 surfaces were defined as the final structure (FS). Fig. 15(b) shows the two reaction pathways of the process. The energies of the transition states during path 1 and path 2 are 0.363 eV, 0.773 eV, 0.499 eV and 1.021 eV, respectively. A comparison of the energies of the transition states indicates that the desorption of CO2 from the surface is the rate-limiting step in both Path 1 and Path 2. The data of Fig. 15(a, b) show that path 1 has lower energy barriers to overcome than path 2, which suggests that path 1 is superior to path 2. Fig. 16 illustrates the entire cycle of CO conversion to CO2. Initially, CO reacts with lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface, resulting in the formation of CO2. Subsequently, O2 is adsorbed onto the surface of CuMn2O4, where one oxygen atom fills the oxygen vacancy. The gas-phase CO then reacts with another oxygen atom to form CO2, effectively restoring the catalyst to its original state. 4 Conclusions In this study, a CuMn2O4 catalyst was synthesized and systematically investigated through experimental analyses and theoretical calculations to mitigate CO content in sintering flue gas. The key conclusions derived from this work are as follows: (1) The catalytic efficiency is 98.34 % at 105 °C when the Cu/Mn ratio is 1:2. Characterization results, including X-ray diffraction (XRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM), confirm the formation of a CuMn2O4 catalyst with enhanced stability and high purity at this ratio. Conversely, an excess of copper leads to an increased proportion of CuO in the catalyst, which adversely affects catalytic activity. (2) Among the four adsorption models, the CO-Mn model demonstrates the highest adsorption energy, indicating a preference for CO adsorption at Mn-top sites. Furthermore, the adsorption energy of the bridge-2 model exceeds that of the bridge-1 model, suggesting that the presence of the copper enhances the activity of the oxygen, resulting in a more stable adsorption structure with CO. (3) The adsorption of CO on the surface of CuMn2O4 (100) resulted in charge transfer, which facilitated the formation of chemical bonds. Furthermore, the results of the density of states analysis indicate that the primary reason for the chemisorption was the hybridization of the orbitals. (4) CO is initially adsorbed at the Mn site, after which it overcomes energy barriers of 0.95 eV and 0.77 eV to reach the transition states TS1 and TS3, respectively. Subsequently, it passes through the transition states TS2 and TS4 before finally overcoming the energy barrier to desorb from the surface. A comparison of the two reaction pathways reveals that pathway 1 requires lower energy to overcome, making it the more favorable route. coredata.dc:description: To reduce the carbon monoxide (CO) emissions in sintering flue gas, this study employed a catalytic oxidation approach to convert CO into carbon dioxide (CO2) at low temperatures. The Cu-Mn catalysts were synthesized using co-precipitation methods. The effects of various reaction conditions, such as the Cu/Mn ratio and reaction temperatures, on CO catalytic efficiency was investigated. The results indicated that when the Cu/Mn ratio was 1:2, the catalytic efficiency was 98.34 % at approximately 105 °C. Furthermore, the catalysts remained stable after continuous testing. Based on density functional theory (DFT), a model for the adsorption of CO molecules was established. The adsorption characteristics between CuMn2O4 and CO, as well as the changes in surface charge distribution before and after adsorption, were systematically investigated. The research results indicated that the adsorption of CO on the surface of CuMn2O4 is a chemical adsorption process. Among the various adsorption sites, CO exhibits a greater affinity for the Mn-top site, with an adsorption energy of − 1.18 eV. During the adsorption process, some electrons from CO are transferred to the surface of the catalyst, resulting in orbital hybridization. Additionally, this paper investigated the reaction pathways involved in the CO oxidation process. These findings provide new insights for the optimization and screening of catalysts, which are significant for the fields of industrial flue gas purification and catalytic science.
coredata.dc:title: Experimental and mechanism investigation on CO catalytic oxidation performance based on CuMn2O4 catalysts
